taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Greek seilenos , probably derived from Silenus, the intoxicated foster father of the Greek god Bacchus, who was described as covered with foam; perhaps allud-ing to the viscid secretion covering many species]

bio:treatment.discussion: Silene includes several important weeds and some very beautiful horticultural plants. In addition to the species described in this account, several others have occurred in the flora area as chance introductions or garden escapes, but they have not become established and most have not been seen recently. They include S. coeli-rosa (Linnaeus) Godron, S. cretica Linnaeus, S. (Lychnis) fulgens (Fischer) E. H. L. Krause, S. italica Persoon, and S. nutans Linnaeus.

In this account, Lychnis, Melandrium, and Viscaria have been included in Silene, their previous recognition as distinct genera having resulted in a great deal of confusion in both nomenclature and taxonomy. I have not presented an infrageneric classification of Silene because existing systems either do not include those other genera (e.g., P. K. Chowdhuri 1957) or do not deal with most of our native North American taxa [e.g., W. Greuter (1995) and the molecular studies by Oxelman and coworkers (e.g., B. Oxelman et al. 1997, 2000]. The recent molecular study by J. G. Burleigh and T. P. Holtsford (2003) provides little support for existing morphologically based sectional classifications within Silene insofar as they relate to endemic North American taxa. However, it does indicate the distinctness of our arctic alpine species (S. involucrata—as S. furcata, and S. acaulis) that are circumpolar in their distribution.

references.reference: Bocquet, G. 1969. Revisio Physolychnidum (Silene Sect. Physolychnis).... Lehre. Burleigh, J. G. and T. P. Holtsford. 2003. Molecular systematics of the eastern North American Silene (Caryophyllaceae): Evidence from nuclear ITS and chloroplast trnL intron sequences. Rhodora 105: 76–90.

Hitchcock, C. L. and B. Maguire. 1947. A Revision of the North American Species of Silene. Seattle. [Univ. Wash. Publ. Biol. 13.] Kruckeberg, A. R. 1962. Intergeneric hybrids in the Lychnideae (Caryophyllaceae). Brittonia 14: 311–321.
McNeill, J. 1978. Silene alba and S. dioica in North America and the generic delimitation of Lychnis, Melandrium and Silene (Caryophyllaceae). Canad. J. Bot. 56: 297–308.
Oxelman, B. and M. Lidén. 1995. Generic boundaries in the tribe Sileneae (Caryophyllaceae) as inferred from nuclear rDNA sequences. Taxon 44: 525–542.
Oxelman, B., M. Lidén, and D. Berglund. 1997. Chloroplast rps16 intron phylogeny of the tribe Sileneae (Caryophyllaceae). Pl. Syst. Evol. 206: 411–420.
Oxelman, B., M. Lidén, R. K. Rabeler, and M. Popp. 2000. A revised generic classification of the tribe Sileneae (Caryophyllaceae). Nordic J. Bot. 20: 743–748.
Williams, F. N. 1896b. A revision of the genus Silene Linn. J. Linn. Soc., Bot. 32: 1–196.

key_statement.description: Stigmas 5 (rarely 4 in individual flowers); capsule with 5–10 teeth (rarely 4 or 8).
Limbs of petals shorter than calyx, not differentiated from claw, ascending to spreading but rarely in horizontal plane; petals off-white, dingy pink, dusky purple, or purple tinged.
Seeds winged.
Calyces inflated in flower or fruit, thin and papery; petals dusky purple-red; seeds 1.5–2.5 mm, with broad wing; flowers nodding (erect in subsp. porsildii but seeds 2–2.5 mm)
Calyces neither inflated nor very thin; petals white or pink; seeds 0.5–1.5 mm, wing often narrow; flowers erect.
Seeds (0.5–)0.8–1(–1.3) mm, wing to ca. 1 / 4 diam. of seed; calyces elliptic, 7–10(–12) mm; stem 2–10(–12) cm; flowers 1(–3)
Seeds 1–1.5 mm, wing to 1 / 2 diam. of seed; calyces often campanulate or ovate, 8–20 mm; stems 10–45 cm; often with 1–3 flowers per peduncle
Seeds not winged.
Fruiting calyces 2–3 times longer than broad, broadly tubular to narrowly ellipsoid
Fruiting calyces to 2 times as long as broad, campanulate, ovate, or elliptic.
Fruiting calyces 10–12 mm, not or only slightly contracted at mouth
Fruiting calyces 13–17 mm, contracted at mouth to 1 / 2 – 2 / 3 diam.
Inflorescences 1(–3)-flowered; pedicels 1 / 2 –3 times calyx, length of pubescence less than 1 / 2 pedicel diam.; veins of calyx prominent

Inflorescences (1–)3-flowered; flowers sessile or pedicellate; pedicels usually much shorter than calyx, longest hairs ca. equaling pedicel or peduncle diam.; veins of calyx partially obscured by dense pubescence

Limbs of petals clearly differentiated from claw, spreading horizontally, equaling or longer than calyx (shorter in S. chalcedonica , S. flos-cuculi , and S. involucrata ); petals showy, scarlet, bright purple or pink, or white.
Inflorescences dense (interrupted in S. viscaria ) cymes of (3–)5–50 flowers; flowers sessile or pedicels shorter than calyx.
Petals scarlet (rarely white or pink); coarse hispid herbs 50–100 cm; leaf blades broadly ovate or elliptic to lanceolate
Petals bright pink or purple (rarely white); glabrous or sparsely pubescent herbs 5–90 cm; leaf blades narrowly lanceolate.
Flowers 14–22 mm diam.; limb of corolla obovate, ± entire; carpophore 3–5 mm; nodes of stem viscid
Flowers 5–10 mm diam.; limb of corolla 2-lobed to middle; carpophore ca. 1 mm; nodes of stem not viscid
Inflorescences open cymes, 1–3 to many-flowered; most pedicels longer than calyx.
Open flowers 8–16 mm diam.
Open flowers 20–35 mm diam.
Petal limbs deeply divided with 4 linear segments
Petal limbs unlobed, emarginate or shallowly 2-lobed.
Leaf blades with dense, silky, grayish white tomentum; flowers bisexual
Pubescence hirsute or sparingly to densely pubescent; flowers unisexual.
Petals white; capsule teeth slightly reflexed or spreading
Petals bright pink; capsule teeth revolute
Stigmas 3 (rarely 4 or 5 in individual flowers, usually 4 in S. scaposa ); capsules with 3 or 6 teeth (rarely 4, 5, 8, or 10).
Petals scarlet.
Limbs of petals unlobed or emarginate, shallowly dentate, or crenate, rarely shallowly 2-lobed.
Stems and leaf blades glabrous
Stems and leaf blades pubescent.
Stems erect, 50–160 cm; inflorescences many-flowered; leaf blades ovate to lanceolate, apex acute, not acuminate
Stems ascending, 10–20 cm; inflorescences with flowers usually solitary, terminal; leaf blades linear-lanceolate, apex sharply acuminate
Limbs of petals deeply lobed or laciniate.
Petals deeply 4–6-lobed, small lateral teeth may be present
Petals deeply 2-lobed, lobes often with lateral teeth.
Leaf blades subrotund to broadly lanceolate; petal lobes ciliate
Leaf blades lanceolate, oblanceolate, or obovate to narrowly elliptic; petal lobes glabrous or nearly so (claw may be ciliate).
Stems 4–10(–15) cm; inflorescences 1–3(–4)-flowered; leaves longest in mid stem, basal tufts absent; w United States
Stems 20–80 cm; inflorescences (3–)7–11(–20)-flowered; leaves longest at base of stem, in basal tufts; e United States
Petals white, cream, pink, or dark red, off-white tinged with purple.
Calyces with 20–30 parallel veins.
Calyces glabrous, veins obscure
Calyces pubescent and usually glandular, veins prominent.
Mature calyces 20–30 mm; seeds 1.3–1.8 mm broad
Calyces 8–15 mm; seeds 0.6–1 mm broad.
Petals ± equaling calyx, limb 1–3 mm, inconspicuous; corollas cream to dull orange abaxially, often purple tinged adaxially; calyx lobes 2–3 mm
Petals much exceeding calyx, conspicuous, limb 3–6 mm; corollas pink (rarely white or dark red); calyx lobes ca. 5 mm
Calyces with 10 or fewer veins or venation obscure.
Inflorescences congested, capitate, or flowers clustered; flowers sessile or pedicels shorter than calyx.
Plants glabrous
Plants pubescent.
Calyx veins purple tinged or entirely purple; corollas rose pink, limb 2-lobed
Calyx veins green; corollas greenish yellow to white, limb deeply lacin- iate into 6 or more linear lobes
Inflorescences open; flowers pedicellate, if pedicels short, then flowers in several separate whorls, or solitary.
Leaves whorled at each node, 4 to many.
Leaf blades lanceolate to ovate-lanceolate, 4 per node
Leaf blades linear to very narrowly elliptic-lanceolate, more than 4 pernode
Leaves opposite, 2 at each node (smaller axillary shoots sometimes present), or all or mostly proximal.
Calyces herbaceous, conspicuous pale commissures between veins absent, veins obscure.
Limbs of petals with several narrow, linear lobes
Limbs of petals unlobed, sometimes emarginate, or 2-lobed.
Calyces glabrous.
Petals bright pink, rarely white
Petals white.
Fruiting calyces ovoid, contracted at mouth to ca. 1 / 2 its diam.; stamens ca. 2 times calyx; filaments purple
Fruiting calyces clavate or campanulate, not contracted at mouth; stamens ca. 1–1 1 / 3 times calyx; filaments usually white.
Fruiting calyces broadly clavate, strongly contracted at base around carpophore; carpophores5–6 mm; inflorescences leafy
Fruiting calyces campanulate, not contracted at base; carpophores 2–3 mm; inflorescences withleaves reduced, resembling bracts
Calyces pubescent.
Seeds winged
Seeds not winged.
Mature calyces contracted towards base around carpophore; carpophores 4–7 mm.
Corollas white; calyces green
Corollas pink (rarely white); calyces purple, purpleveined, or purple tinged
Mature calyces not contracted at base; carpophores less than 2 mm.
Leaf blades oblanceolate to elliptic-lanceolate, rarely obovate or elliptic, broadest distally or atmiddle
Leaf blades narrowly lanceolate to elliptic- or ovate-lanceolate, broadest proximally.
Petals dark red (rarely white); calyces 6–9 ×3–4 mm
Petals white; calyces 9–11 × 4–6 mm
Calyces with pale commissures between prominent parallel veins.
Plants annual or biennial, often with slender taproot.
Mature calyces clavate, urceolate, or fusiform, contracted proximally around carpophore.
Petals white, often pink tinged
Petals bright pink.
Petals unlobed
Petals 2-lobed
Mature calyces campanulate, elliptic, or ovoid, not contracted at base around carpophore.
Stems subglabrous to puberulent, often glutinous on distal internodes
Stems coarsely hispid.
Mature calyces (7–)10–15 mm; seeds grayish brown to black, ca. 1 mm
Mature calyces 7–10 mm; seeds dark reddish brown, ca. 0.5 mm diam.;stems 15–45 cm
Plants perennial, rhizomatous or with stout, often woody taproot and branched (or sometimes in S. oregana ), woody caudex.
Calyx lobes equaling or exceeding tube
Calyx lobes shorter than tube.
Mature calyces clavate, funnelform, turbinate, urceolate, tubular, or fusiform, narrowed proximally around carpophore.
Corolla limbs unlobed or nearly so
Corolla limbs lobed or laciniate.
Calyx lobes 4–8 mm, lanceolate or narrowly triangular.
Corollas coral pink, pink, or white, limb 7–25 mm; calyces umbilicate or turbinate in fruit.
Corolla limbs laciniate into many narrow segments; calyces thinly pilose,funnelform in flower, umbilicate in fruit
Corolla limbs 4-lobed, usually deeply so, rarely 2-lobed with 2 smaller lateral teeth; calyces canescent, eglandular or glandular, broadly tubular inflower, turbinate in fruit
Corollas pale greenish yellow or pale yellow to white, sometimes purple tinged, limb 5–8 mm; calyces clavate in fruit.
Corolla limbs deeply laciniate into 6 or more linear lobes; calyces (20–)25–30 mm, densely puberulent and viscid-glandular, tubular in flower
Corolla limbs cleft ca. to middle into (2–)4–8 lanceolate to oblong lobes; calyces 16–20 mm, densely and coarsely pubescent and viscid-glandular,tubular to narrowly obconic in flower
Calyx lobes 2–4 mm, lanceolate to ovate or triangular-acute, or 2–5 mm with broad, obtuse, membranous margins.
Leaf blades ovate-acuminate, sessile; mature calyces turbinate
Leaf blades linear or spatulate to ovate-lanceolate or oblanceolate, at least proximal ones petiolate; mature calyces clavate to tubular or fusiform.
Corolla limbs pink or rose red (rarely white), (7–)10–20 mm, with 4 (rarely 2 with 2 teeth) divergent, lanceolate lobes; mature calyces 15–38 mm
Corolla limbs white, greenish, pink, or dingy red, 3–8 mm, with 2–6(–10) linear lobes; mature calyces 8–17(–20) mm.
Corolla limbs 2-lobed (rarely with small lateral teeth).
Inflorescences open cymes with many elongate, ascending branchesand pedicels longer than calyx
Inflorescences pseudoracemose and nodding with flowers usually paired at nodes and pedicels ± equaling calyx, or erect with dense, many-flowered whorls and most flowers sessile or shortlypedicellate
Corolla limbs 4–6-lobed.
Corolla appendages 2, laciniate, apex rounded, 2–3 mm; claw andfilaments ciliate; corolla lobes 4, linear
Corolla appendages 4–6, linear, apex acute, 1–1.5 mm; claw and filaments glabrous; corolla lobes 4–6, often forked, producing to 10 linear segments
Mature calyces campanulate, elliptic, or ovate, not contracted proximally around carpophore, or if so, broadly turbinate or obconic, at least 1 / 2 as broad as long.
Styles exceeding 2 times calyx; stamens exserted from calyx.
Leaves mostly in dense basal tufts
Leaves mostly cauline
Styles and stamens ± equaling calyx and/or corolla.
Sepals and pedicels without glandular hairs.
Petals to 2 times calyx
Petals slightly longer than calyx
Glandular hairs present at least on pedicels and calyces.
Leaves mostly basal, densely tufted, cauline leaves usually in 1–3 pairs and/or reduced.
Corollas slightly longer than sepals, limbs 1–2 mm, unlobed, or apex notched
Corollas exceeding or sometimes equaling calyces; limbs 2–10 mm, 2(–4)-lobed.
Plants small alpine species; stems 3–20(–30) cm; leaf blades fleshy, 0.5–5(–6) cm.
Pubescence on calyces and pedicels with purple septa
Pubescence on calyces and pedicels with colorless septa.
Seeds 2–3 mm, margins thickened and winglike; proximal leaf blades oblanceolate-spatulate, 2–7 mm wide
Seeds ca. 1.5 mm, margins with large inflated papillae; proximal leaf blades linear-oblanceolate, 0.5–3 mm wide
Plants lowland and montane species; stems usually exceeding 30 cm; leaf blades not fleshy, 2–15 cm.
Calyx lobes narrowly lanceolate with narrow membranous margins proximally
Calyx lobes ovate to broadly triangular with broad membranous margins.
Claws of corollas exceeding calyx, ciliate proximally; veins to calyx lobes conspicuously broadened distally and lance-shaped, commissural veins slender, not forked distally
Claws of corollas equaling calyx, glabrous; veins of calyx lobes not conspicuously broadened distally, commissural veins slender and forked distally, connate with those to lobes
Basal leaves not densely tufted; cauline leaves in 3–12 pairs.
Cymes sessile (proximal ones may be pedunculate); pedicels usually shorter than calyxand becoming deflexed at base of calyx
Cymes pedunculate or flowers solitary; pedicels shorter than to exceeding calyx, ascending (may be partially deflexed in S. thurberi and S. petersonii ).
Petals bright pink, limb 5–15 mm; plants rhizomatous from thick rootstock; stems5–15 cm
Petals white, pale pink, or yellowish, often tinged green or dusky purple, limb 3–8 mm; plants not rhizomatous; stems erect, usually exceeding 15 cm.
Pubescence on calyces and pedicels short, deflexed, grayish white, eglandular(glandular hairs often present in var. rupinae )
Pubescence scabrid-puberulent or often viscid glandular-pubescent with septate hairs, glandular hairs present at least distally.
Mature calyces ca. as broad as long; flowers nocturnal
Mature calyces ca. 2 times as long as broad, flowers diurnal.
Corolla limbs 5–7 mm, mature calyces 12–16 mm; stems softly viscid-puberulent distally
Corolla limbs 2–4 mm, mature calyces 7–12 mm; stems scabridpuberulent.
Calyx lobes 1–2 mm, ovate, as long as broad, corolla appendagesentire
Calyx lobes 3–4 mm, narrowly lanceolate, much longer than broad, corolla appendages erose
